Name: The Theoretical Minimum: What You Need to Know to Start Doing Physics

ReviewList.Text: I majored in humanities but I'm interested in math and science, and I find this book both challenging and rewarding. But as I worked through it I found a number of things that looked wrong. Eventually I Googled the book's web site and found an Errata file that I downloaded. It identified 58 errors, most of them in equations and many of them significant enough to thoroughly befuddle a careful reader who trusted the book as written. That's an appalling number of errors. Somebody at Basic Books ought to be looking for a new job. I recommend the book if you are interested and willing to read carefully, but if you can't wait for a second, corrected printing be sure to download the Errata before you dig in!

This looked interesting but I gave up because I found the equation fonts frustratingly tiny and faint on the Kindle edition. I'll buy a hard copy but it would be great if people creating Kindle editions thought more about formatting and layout issues for books like this.

Unfortunately the Kindle edition is completely unreadable on my device because of the very, VERY small equations throughout the book -- practically everything that's not plain text is way too small to read, and it can't be scaled up along with the text. And it's a real shame, too, because the content seems quite well put together; unfortunately the issue is so damaging to readability that I had to return the book, despite the fact that I really enjoyed the first few sections I read -- imagine my frustration. I tried to read it on a Samsung Galaxy S3, which I successfully used to read several other books, including books about physics, statistics and maths in general.

but, the math is not, at least for me; this is definitely not a book for a total beginner. Lots of differential, partial differential, and integral calculus, Poisson brackets, as well as vectors/linear algebra. The 'good news' is that readers will receive more than the minimum necessary to understand basic classical physics and the material covers Newtonian mechanics, electromagnetic fields, and basic thermodynamics. The book summarizes a course taught by Susskind to residents living near Stanford - I suspect his attendees are mostly graduate-level engineers.

Those of you who have watched the lectures from which this book came, be aware that this book does not cover nearly all the subjects covered in the lectures.  The lectures span everything from classical physics to issues in string theory.  This book only covers classical physics.  Perhaps there are more books to come.

The author is clear in his explanations making the book easy to follow. However, there are just too many errors in this first edition.  Hopefully, there will be a new edition published in the meantime go to [...]

If you've watched the online lectures on Mechanics, you'll instantly recognize the first introductory chapter and some of the later chapters too (Lagrangian and Hamiltonian formulations). I really like the mano-e-mano format. Its not daunting and you get the feeling a friend is hand holding you all the way through. Now I hope there will be some follow up maths books to the Quantum Mechanics, General Relativity and Statistical Mechanics online courses as well. It'll then truly become the 21st century equivalent of the Feynman Lectures books of the 20th century. Great job you guys. I am happy to be owning and thank you so very much to put a smile on my wallet as well. Its the cost of two Sandwiches in Manhattan and a bag of chips only this stays fresh and lasts longer. Should we start calling it the little white book you can tuck in your bag with your iPad. I love it. Modern Physics and its mathematical accouterments have truly arrived to the common man through the vision of two men. I think this is re-birth of the cool!

This book assumes you are willing to exert some mathematical effort to understand what's happening.  If you are, then you'll be well rewarded with clear explanations and a sense of awe over how things work.  If you aren't, don't consider the book at all. The math isn't vicious.  If you ever took calculus at all,you'll be fine.  I almost failed it in colledge, but I recall enough to handle what the author is throwing.

I never took physics and last did calculus 25 years ago. This book lost me after 10 pages. Endless equations and not nearly enough explanation. The reviews said it was a book that was good if you hadn't had physics, but this was not the case.

This is possibly a useful book if you are a member of the right audience. I was looking for a physics refresher using calculus that that presented a modern approach to applied physics. That isn't what the authors mean by doing physics. A more apt title would have been: The minimum you need to know to start doing theoretical physics.

Kindle Edition has unreadable equations; otherwise the book seems well organized and written.  Don't get the Kindle edition.  I am going to look for a PDF after I return this Kindle edition for a refund.

I studied mathematics in college but do not use much beyond a little statistics now.  Every once in a while, I get an urge to do a little work and apply myself to something a bit more technical.  This book does not really demand much technically but wow does it deliver on content. I remember studying Bessel functions, Legendre polynomials, and wave equations in my first year but then we moved onto more formal definitions, theorems, and other useful concepts.  To think what I behind.  To think that I helped my physics and chemistry major friends with introductory group theory when they had all this fun stuff about how the world works running around in their brains.  And they never shared!  Now for less than 10 minutes cost of instruction time in college, I get to have the wonderment now that I missed then.

By trade I am a doctor and my mathematics and physics are only at high school level. Yet, I still enjoy this book. The ultimate insight the book tries to tell the reader and prove is: "The laws of physics involve gauge fields, but objective phenomena are gauge invariant." I have always wanted to know what gauge invariance actually means, so this book to me is rewarding. As expected, Lagrangian and Hamiltonian formulations are introduced and explained. With these, the nature of Noether's theorem and ultimately gauge, among other things, are described. There are quite a lot of aha moments. Not necessarily easy to follow fully but unfortunately a must-read if one wants to understand quantum mechanics, which will be dealt with in the next installment.

I am not sure what the point of this book is. It claims to introduce the necessary material of a first course in physics, including the relevant mathematics, but it instead seems to cram two years of math into ~200 pages and then go straight to advanced mechanics. While it's supposedly appropriate for a dedicated lay reader, how anyone who doesn't already have a STEM background is expected to make sense of this book is a mystery--I have taken calculus, diff eq, analysis, etc. and I was completely lost after 80 pages or so. Newton's Laws of Gravitation get a passing mention in the appendix. If this is a "first course," I suppose there must be some zeroth course lurking about that they expect you to take first. Either that, or the book is really meant as a textbook to go with the online lectures from which it was originally derived.

This is a beautifully "economic" summary of the key concepts underlying the most common models used in theoretic physics.  It provides very clear explanations, at the right level of generality, of the bigger picture, i.e., how it all works together. Susskind and Hrabovsky explain the key formulas with rare and concise clarity.  Highly recommended. A great basis for further reading in physics.

So why does Amazon Kindle reader make it damn near impossible to read equations by making them unable to resize with the rest of the text?  Great book by the way but DO NOT buy the Kindle version. Otherwise five stars!

It's a very challenging book to understand for someone who doesn't have a background in advanced mathematics' and physics' courses. I enjoyed the challenge, especially because it teaches some of the mathematics required for understanding difficult physics' topics such as Quantum Mechanics and Relativity. For instance, I often saw Lagrangians and Hamiltonians mentioned in Wiki Physics' articles I couldn't understand, and now I can understand those articles a little bit better. On the negative side there is an extensive errata list and I wish there were more problems solved in the text. Difficult problem solutions, which should have been illustrated in the text, are left for the reader to work out. Even highly skilled Physics' majors would have difficulty solving some of the problems, although the book was written for the intelligent layman who just wants a better understanding of difficult concepts in Physics and is not a Physics' major at a top-tier school such as Stanford, where the book was written.

This book goes along well with Dr. Susskind's Stanford lectures.  I'm one of the frustrated ex-physics grads for which the book (and lectures) was written. I ended up doing electronics engineering, but my real love is physics. I've tried to get smarter and keep up since I graduated many years ago. The book assumes you have some calculus and trig under your belt. It's get's into partial derivatives fairly quickly (Lecture 3, pg. 74). I also bought "Quantum Mechanics" that goes along with the Theoretical Minimum set of lectures. I appreciate Dr. Susskind spending the time and energy (no pun intended) in preparing the couses and writing the books. Highly recommended.

The figures cannot be interpreted.  Book is useless in the kindle format.  I love books printed in Kindle form.  I can enlarge the type to a font that my eighty-two year old eyes can read without glasses.  But my Kindle version of Prof. Susskind's "Theoretical Minimum ......." was a sad disappointment.  The print was wonderful. but the equations and figures were too small to be interpreted.  Is it possible to re-format technical books of this sort to bring out the graphics in Kindle form ?

If you never took physics in college but still want to understand the relationship between classical mechanics and (simple) calculus, or wonder about what a phase space is or why conservation of energy is intimately connected with time, this book will walk you through quite a few concepts from scratch.  (There are a few suggested exercises to work on along the way, and as with any math or physics class these concepts won't really settle in unless you try them out and see how they work in practice.)

An admirable attempt to provide a low-cost education in some of the basic mathematics of theoretical physics.  But I am surprised that the first edition of the book was so widely endorsed, given that there were so many errors.  Some other reviews have pointed this out.  The Revised Edition still has some serious errors.  Go to scribd, search for the book title, then click the Documents tab.  You will find a recent errata document, unavailable at the book website.

Don't buy this book!! I got 20 pages or so into it and couldn't take the so small almost non-existent equations. Something happened in the printing that they're so small. The words are OK and move along, but the equations are necessary for full understanding of the text and contents. How this escaped the proofreaders and Amazon beats me. I'm thinking about getting this as paperback, but I break into a cold sweat every time I think about picking up a page book.

Terrific book to give you the core concepts from classical mechanics.  Very clearly described.  Provides the math without doing an exposition requiring huge commitment of time and attention.  A breakthrough, it fills a niche that has long been empty.
For a few dollars as a kindle-book, I've understood something I've wondered about for forty years.  The Hamilton comes next but not in this book.

Two years of algebra and one of geometry are not enough. Maybe it was too long ago. I might enjoy this book if it came with a tutor who could answer endless questions. Not a real person, necessarily, but a hologram or robot would be nice.

The equations are very difficult to read on Kindle. It is awkward to zoom in on the equations, and even then they are very fuzzy. There is not much point in the book if you can't read the equations. I finally gave up on the book.
I was surprised that, @ 85 years of age, so much had been forgotten.  Nothing wrong with the book.  I have a BA (with math science minors) + JD but this book was beyond my skill level.
Even I, over 50 years removed from calculus and differential equations, was able to understand the lectures. I recommend this for everyone interested in the basics of classical physics.
Using this as text book and the online lectures one can educate himself in the principles of classical mechanics in a week. Please write one for statistical mechanics!
A++ Real physics properly explained.  Susskind opens the beautiful world of physics to anyone willing to put in the minimum work required.
My daughter's boyfriend asked for this book for Christmas.  He was very excited when he opened it on Christmas morning.

I have been trolling the internet for years trying to find someone who explains the concept of the Lagrangian to me in an understandable way -- without success UNTIL i checked out Susskind's book on Amazon using the 'Surprise me' feature. It happened to take me to the section explaining what the Lagrangian is about. It blew my mind how accessible he has made it. If only for that bit alone the book is worth buying. It's a shame that physics education is MADE unnecessarily inaccessible to the intelligent and interested masses . Anybody wanna guess why that is ?

Be careful what you wish for: I wanted a quick and focused trip through all the physics I wish I had learned in high school and the book certainly takes you on that tour. However, be prepared to do some more reading on your own as the explanations can be very brief. You always get the general point but may not be clear on how to apply it. Example: vector addition is nicely demonstrated and then the author says "can you figure out how to subtract vectors?". Err....

It is a much needed "text book" that is rigorous and also provides considerable expository insight to help the reader understand concepts and relevancy of the critical formalism that transitions from classical physics to the startling developments of the 20th century.  Finer steps in the mathematical derivations would have merited the fifth star.

This should really be the physics 101 text used to introduce students to real physics without getting into intense problems. Learning math the way susskind does it is truly the best way. I recommend this for the general public, high school seniors interested in studying science, and for physics professors hoping to teach some sort of introductory course.
Well written complement to Prof. Sussknid's on-line lecture series.
Good intro to physics, but more math than some might like.
The introduction shows good tools for understanding and gives clear concepts. At the end you must be with open eyes because the Hamiltonian its a hard concept.

Rigorous approach to classical mechanics with lots of serious math.  Not for the faint of heart.  This book succeeds in making you feel like a student in a university-level physics class listening to a professor writing equations at the blackboard.  That may or may not be what you actually want.

To fully understand the book, you will have to work through some math.  Also, I found that I had to stop occasionally and think through what I had just read until it made sense.  It is not a quick, or a particularly elegant, read but is is fascinating.
Boyfriend loved it, he wanted to do some independent study on physics and this book is perfect for that. It's very understandable and gives you the basics to apply to other things.
This is only for the classical mechanics course-- not the more interesting relativity or other ones as I had hoped. So, be warned.
Its a good book and one should probably watch the videos of the same to get the most out of it.  There are definitely a few typos in it which hopefully a new edition will fix.
This is a pretty good book. It's very aggressive and fast paced, but perfectly manageable for anyone with just a high school background in mathematics and physics.
Great book to encourage our high school granddaughter who's in a family of physics teachers and professors.  And one's acquainted with the author.
Excellent description of the basic concepts in mechanics. Well written and very easy to understand despite the technical concepts involved.

This author is in love with the beauty of math, and it shows.  Unfortunately it touches only tangentially on the connection with physics, and is undeveloped in this regard.  If you love higher math, this could be fun except that it will be old hat.  It is certainly not a primer on the relationships between math and physics, and it is far too advanced for the layperson (and I DID take differential equations in college).  A tough slog, and NOT for one without advanced math training.
Great review of classical mechanics. Unfortunately, I need more review so I'll need to read it again.
A short and sweet explanation of the fundamental concepts and techniques of classical mechanics.
Bought this for my scientist husband and he loves it.  Not sure why, but I leave that to him.
Nice review of the physics and the math you need.  This was worth every penny, and more.
Accessible, fun, easy way to expand your ways of thinking and ability to problem solve.
Great book - the world needs more people like Leonard Susskind.  A gift to the world.
I've read this minimum I have been raising up my love to physics from this minumum !
Very difficult reading if you are not well versed in physics and math. I wish I did not buy it.

Good explanation, but probably not what most people would expect. That is, physics is as much (or more) mathematics as it is finding out what angle to shoot a cannon ball at in order to hit a target. This book makes it clear that you must know how to take the partial derivative of a function and at least have a fair understanding of integration. Insofar as the book's title is concerned, it is correct. This is certainly the minimum you must know to start doing physics. The key word here is start, because these concepts must be developed and applied even further in understanding quantum mechanics, and QM is something every physicist must know to get even an undergraduate degree.
Ordered book based on WSJ article. 1st chapter is to detailed for a refresher book. Enjoyed the book 6 Easy Pieces better.
Hard to read, and includes some "refresher" info on stuff like differential calculus.  I'm an engineer, and I think I could have written it more clearly, without the "fillers".
Hrabovsky is my son.  He worked on this book, doing all the problem solving with the aid of Mathmatica, don't leave him out of this book.
Fun book on a nice mellow day to read.
Good book, but not that easy to read.
Excellent book and excellent service!
Finally I have a good grasp of QM
If you want to brush up on physics this book used in conjunction with Leonard Susskind's lectures will do it. Especially good for Physics wantabes.
Light reading with some mathematics. Enjoy how classical mechanics developed from the perspective of information theory. I'm grateful to the authors who put the book together.
Errata is a must with this one. Also, the mathematics is sometimes way to sloppy for my taste, but it seems like this is the way they do it in physics departments
excellent

This is not another "popular" treatment, it is real physics.  This little book is true to its name, it is physics and the math needed to master the minimum a student or amateur physicist needs to think about the physics world, read real professional papers and move forward in your understanding.  I look forward to the next installment.

The first chapter seems to be about the fact that for every action there is an equal and opposite reaction but the chapter did not say that in so many words.  I have a degree in electrical engineering and I felt intimidated by the book.  I had planned to give it to my grandson that hopes to go to engineering school next year but I was not comfortable with that decision after scanning this book.  Yes, I have been out of school a long time but if I were writing this book it would be easier to read.

If you like and understand calculus, derivatives, and differential equations you'll like this book.  If you don't, spend your money elsewhere.  The authors did a good job explaining the math used in classical physics.  I guess I was looking for a book that would discuss applications of classical physics.  This was way more math than I wanted.  Great review book if you want to brush up on college level mathematics.
Excellent all the way around. I would buy from them again. Very satisfied overall.

This an excellent classical physics book. It explains many approaches that your typical University Physics textbook leaves out, including Lagrangian and Hamiltonian Mechanics, Symmetry, and Poisson Brackets. It also reviews the math necessary to carry out the physics problems.
Arrived as promised

When the preface of the book states "no equations", I put the book back on the shelf. This book doesn't take that approach. I'm just starting but so far it looks very good. You won't simply "read" this book; you'll need to "work" your way through it with notes and working on the problems it poses. Hopefully the result will be an expanded understanding of modern physics. I'll update my review when I finish the book.
I enjoyed the book but the explainations were not as easy as the reviews made out in the newspapers. Take time to read but worth the effort to get a grasp on some basic physics.
as ad
Agreat book. Well written and a pleasure to read. One of the best physics books I have read. Highly recommended.
I had a some problems whit the math, but it's fantastic book for reach the minimun if you realy like phisics.

I have a degree in Textile Engineering so I know a thing or two about math.  I thought this book was excellent in that it clearly shows how the fabric of the cosmos works and how everything knits together like an expensive cardigan.
It was for my husband: it was a little hard to read, probably since He'd been away from it for so long.
This is a sacrificial case.  If you drop the phone you need a new case.  Having said that it adds neither bulk not weight to the phone and I like that.
Was really not the book he expected and has not had time to get into it - difficult reading, but he'll give it a go.
If you're reading this book with difficulty then you need to put it down and take up knitting with Raj.
